Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Maintain laboratory equipment and ensure safety protocols are followed
Situation2: A safety audit is scheduled shortly, and minor issues with equipment have already been flagged.
Story: I stared at my phone, rereading my brother’s message about the family trip this weekend. Mom was so excited, and I could almost hear her voice urging me to join, reminding me how rare it was for all of us to be together. I knew how much it meant to them, especially after how distant I’d been lately. But as I glanced at the lab schedule on my computer, my stomach tightened. The safety audit was on Monday, and the last inspection had already flagged a few minor issues with the centrifuge and chemical storage. As the lead scientist, it was my responsibility to make sure everything was perfect—one overlooked detail could mean a shutdown or worse, someone getting hurt. My team was counting on me, and I couldn’t just leave them to handle it alone. The weight of both worlds pressed on me, my family’s expectations pulling me one way, my professional duty tugging the other. I sat at my desk, torn, wishing I could be in two places at once.
